Poly(A) +cDNA was transcribed in vitro by incorporation of biotinylated CTP and UTP (Enzo Diagnostics, Farmingdale, NY) using a BioArray High Yield RNA Transcript Labeling kit according to the manufacturer's instructions.
All normalization factors were within 10% of 1. Statistical curve fitting was carried out using GraphPad Prism 2.01.
The marginal increase in the signal after 32 hours of hybridization, though, suggests that thermodynamic equilibrium was not quite reached in 16 hours.

Comparison of absolute values of probe intensities across the different experimental conditions of the study suggest that thermodynamic equilibrium may be dominated by stable nonspecific interactions essentially decreasing target availability (that is, cross-target bridges) in the presence of complex cRNA.

At high concentrations (above 100 pM level), the rate of increase of the MM signal can eclipse that of the PM signal (Figures 1d, 2d, Table 1for PheX_3) resulting in an eventual decline in the ADI (Figures 1d, 2dfor PheX_3).

At high concentrations (above 100 pM level), the rate of increase of the MM signal can eclipse that of the PM signal (Figures 1d, 2d, Table 1for PheX_3) resulting in an eventual decline in the ADI (Figures 1d, 2dfor PheX_3).
Of practical consideration is the ability of the system to provide a robust, directional measure of transcript levels.
Perhaps scanning images before and after amplification could maximize detection without suffering saturation penalties.

At high concentrations (above 100 pM level), the rate of increase of the MM signal can eclipse that of the PM signal (Figures 1d, 2d, Table 1for PheX_3) resulting in an eventual decline in the ADI (Figures 1d, 2dfor PheX_3).
Consequently, the ADI decreases for high target concentrations where the slope of the PM sigmoidal has tapered.

An increase in the number of replicates is preferable to reliance upon magnitudes of fold changes, as the latter is not always linearly related to target concentration and is extremely variable for low transcript concentrations.

The prokaryotic controls used in this study contain engineered poly(A) +tails and are available through the American Type Culture Collection [ 10] ( dapB , ATCC 87486; lysA , ATCC 87482; pheB , ATCC 87483; and thrC , ATCC 87484).

The premise that subtraction of the MM from PM essentially serves to extract constructively the nonspecific components (cross-hybridization, noise, and so on) of the signal common to both should be reconsidered in the light of the results obtained in this study.
The stratification of nonspecific interactions unique to or common to the PM and MM signals was not addressed.
As evidenced by the range bars in Figures 1and 2, the variability of actual transcript intensities appears to increase with concentration.
For the 0.1 pM target concentration, all 12 target transcripts were detectable in the absence of brain cRNA background.
Additionally, the increase in signal for the 10 pM level remained consistently less than half of that obtained in the absence of complex cRNA.
